answers.body_markdown:
See https://www.npmjs.com/package/gh-pages#basic-usage

What you need to do is create a js script to use the module. I would suggest you create it under a `scripts` directory under the root of your project.

Paste the code you need to run. I recommend the following for configuring uploading to a public directory:

`ghpages.publish(
    'public',
    {
        branch: 'master',
        repo: '',
    },
    () => {
        console.log('Deploy Complete!')
    }
)`

Enter your repo property. => defines the callback function outputting to the console.

Next, open package.json under the root of your project directory. You will see "scripts" defined with default Gatsby scripts, you will need to add one for deployment.

Add the following at the end:
`deploy:github": "npm run build && node ./scripts/deploy-github"`

Save the file, execute `npm run` and you will see the list of scripts you can execute. Execute `npm run deploy:github` when you want to deploy.

answers.body_markdown:
**Absolutely. With no gotchas.**

> 1. Transient objects are always different; a new instance is provided to every injection.
> 
> 2. Scoped objects are the same within a request, but different across different requests.

Which means that your scoped objects which are created in every request can be injected with a transient class which will be newly created just for that specific injection.

An example use case would be:

1. You have a custom made class implementing `ICollection`, which utilizes a randomizer seeded by current timestamp when it was created and you written those logic in its constructor.
2. You have a scoped service class injected into a controller. This service depend on previous class to do some logic.
3. Every time the former class was injected into the latter class, it will be newly created, seeded with current timestamp at its creation.

answers.body_markdown:
Thanks for your interest in Yugabyte DB! This is definitely a great use-case. Please see the answers inline.

> I’m interested in global replication with YugaByte. At the moment I have built an abstraction over BadgerDB,  a Key-Value database written in GoLang. Our abstraction maintains indexes, is kind of graphql-ish, and extremely FAST. Is it possible to  use YugaByte DB with global replication as a Key Value store, instead of GoLang? I’m aiming for the performance of KeyValue, Globally Distributed.

Yes, you can absolutely achieve a high-peformance, globally distributed key-value deployment with Yugabyte DB. You can see an example of a [globally distributed deployment here][1].

> As I understand the speed of writes decreases with each additional replicated node. Is that right? Is it possible to instead favour speed and have an eventually-consistent model across the nodes instead? 

As a general rule, yes, latency increases with replication factor. Replication factor is primarily meant to improve fault tolerance, but looks like you want to serve reads close to the end user. In this scenario, you have two options:

* **Read Replicas** are a read-only extension to the *primary data* in the cluster. In this scenario, the primary data of the cluster is deployed across multiple zones in one region, or across nearby regions. Read replicas do not add to the write latencies since the write does not synchronously replicate data to them - the data gets replicated to read replicas asynchronously. You can write to a replica, but the write gets internally redirected to the source of truth.

* **Multi-master deployments** are currently being released as a part of our 2.0 version in beta. This feature allows *independent* clusters to replicate to each other with *last writer wins* semantics. Here is a [detailed design doc about multi-master deployments][2].

Assuming you want global reads and a single cluster, I think read replicas may be what you are looking for.
 
> So we need an authentication layer on the server between YugaByte and the client, ideally this layer would provide the same abstraction we currently have written in Go.

Yes, Yugabyte DB supports [authentication and RBAC for authorization][3] in the Go client drivers.

> What about load-balancing between nodes routing requests to the closest geographical location?

The YCQL API currently supports reading from the nearest geographic region today, so you should be able to achieve this easily already. The YCQL API is semi-relational, but for purposes of a key-value app, that should suffice plenty!

Hope that helps, and let me know if you have any further questions!


  [1]: https://docs.yugabyte.com/latest/manage/enterprise-edition/create-universe-multi-region/
  [2]: https://github.com/YugaByte/yugabyte-db/blob/master/architecture/design/multi-region-2DC-deployment.md
  [3]: https://docs.yugabyte.com/latest/secure/
answers.title: How to setup YugabyteDB as eventually consistent distributed key-value database?

answers.body_markdown:
> As I understand the speed of writes decreases with each additional replicated node. Is that right? 

The previous answer assumes that `additional replicated node` is in fact an additional replica. However, if it means a new node in the cluster, then the answer is that **a new node does not increase write latency**. A new node simply provides more write (and read) throughput to the cluster since it can now host some of the leader and follower shards (aka tablets) present in the cluster. Latency of a key-value write operation is controlled by Replication Factor (RF) of the cluster where typical RF is 3 for production deployments. In such deployments, each shard will have 3 replicas located at 3 separate nodes of the cluster. A write has to commit at the leader replica and at least 1 of the 2 follower replicas before the operation is acknowledged back to the application client as successful. In summary, the latency of write operations increase only when either or both of the following actions are taken:

1. increase the geographical distance between the nodes hosting the 3 replicas 

2. increase the RF from say 3 to 5 (which would lead to 3 out of 4 replicas needing to commit the write before client ack).

> Is it possible to instead favour speed and have an eventually-consistent model across the nodes instead?

**Eventual consistency is not possible in Yugabyte DB** given the reliance on per-shard distributed consensus (using Raft as the consensus protocol) among nodes that process write requests. You can review how Raft differs from eventual consistency in this post [How Does Consensus-Based Replication Work in Distributed Databases?][1] under the "Paxos/Raft vs. Non-Consensus Replication Protocols" section. As highlighted in the previous answer, when cross-region write latency is a concern, the solution is to use asynchronous replication across regions using either Read Replica Clusters (for powering timeline-consistent reads in regions faraway from the regions taking write requests) or Multi-Master Clusters (for powering writes in multiple regions with conflicting write requests resolved through Last Writer Wins).

  [1]: https://blog.yugabyte.com/how-does-consensus-based-replication-work-in-distributed-databases/

answers.body_markdown:
I don't think conditional constraints they way you have implemented them will work.

Instead for conditional constraints like this you will need to reformulate the problem to make use of indicator variables, which are binary variables which track the condition (true or false) that you are interested in.

For your specific problem I would suggest something like the following, have a set of variables, say `x1[seg]` for each material that tracks the No. bought up to the benchmark, and then another set of variables, say `x2[seg]` that tracks the No. bought above the benchmark, and finally a set of binary variables, say `z[seg]` which tracks whether we have reached the price break-point.

The cost terms would then each be:

    x1[seg]*price_A_dic[seg] + x2[seg]*price_B_dic[seg]

We then need to add constraints which enforce the variables to take on appropriate values. I think the following should work:

    x1[seg] >= 0
    x1[seg] >= benchmark_dic[seg] * z[seg]
    x2[seg] >= 0
    x2[seg] <= z[seg]*MAX_POSSIBLE_ORDER

Where `MAX_POSSIBLE_ORDER` is some upper bound that we would never exceed in terms of purchase quantity. You can see that in order for `z[seg]` to take on value `1` we first have to order the `benchmark_dic[seg]` quantity at the higher price. Similarly we can only order any at the lower price if `z[seg]` taknes on value `1`.

There may be a neater/more efficient way to do this, but the above should work.

items.body_markdown:
Since we migrated from JEE to Spring, we lost in the ActiveMQ console the dlqDeliveryFailure cause ("cause: null") :

    java.lang.Throwable: Exceeded redelivery policy limit:RedeliveryPolicy {destination = null, collisionAvoidanceFactor = 0.15, maximumRedeliveries = 0, maximumRedeliveryDelay = -1, initialRedeliveryDelay = 5000, useCollisionAvoidance = false, useExponentialBackOff = false, backOffMultiplier = 5.0, redeliveryDelay = 5000}, cause:null

By looking the spring jms and activemq code, I discover this :

 1. ActiveMq purpose two ways of consumption :
    1. Consuming synchronously by calling MessageListener
    2. Consuming asynchronously by enqueueing and let the client calling receive()

Only the first way retrieve the cause on a fail by calling .setRollbackCause() :

    md.setRollbackCause(e);

By using the second way, there is no possibilities for Spring to specify the cause.


So, as a conclusion, I would say there is no support of rollbackcause feature when using ActiveMq with Spring JMS in an asynchronous way.

Am I right ?
items.title: ActiveMQ dlqDeliveryFailureCause with cause null by using Spring @JmsListener

answers.body_markdown:
From your question I conclude that you have a git repo with 3 branches solution-1, solution-2 & solution-3. 

Now when you run the below command

    git checkout solution-1 && git checkout solution-2 && git checkout solution-3

you get correct output because the git checkout gets a valid branch name each time (it ran 3 time with different branch name).

Now, lets see why you get error when running below command,
 

    git branch | grep solution- | cut -c 3- | xargs git checkout

Running the above command is **equivalent to running** ,

    git checkout solution-1 solution-2 solution-3

which will prompt you the **same error**. This is because git checkout only executed one time with **solution-1 as branch** name and solution-2 & solution-3 as file names.

Now, you actually want to switch branches one by one for each argument from xargs. To do this you can run the below command.

 

    git branch | grep solution- | cut -c 3- | xargs -d '\n' -n1  git checkout

answers.body_markdown:
Firstly, you need to configure your web servers to serve your site on any domain.  In Apache, this is done by modifying your `VirtualHost` configuration, like so:

    <VirtualHost *:80>

Also, make sure that this config is loaded first.  (For more details see:  https://stackoverflow.com/q/5427379/362536)

Next, you'll have your users set up CNAME records on their DNS server that points their hostname to yours.  This makes it so that their hostname resolves to the same network addresses as your hostname.  Note that they cannot set a CNAME record for the top-level domain.

You will probably also want to have a place in your site where the user can configure which hostname(s) they're using.

Finally, you need a way to handle these paths that don't have `user-a` in them.  There are two ways to do this.  The first is to modify your rewrite rules to handle these paths directly, and use the `Host` request header in your application to figure out how to handle it.

The second way is to actually use your rewrite rules to inject the `Host` header value into the URL, which then you can read in your application.  Here's an example from the [Apache documentation][1]:

    RewriteRule  "^/(.*)$"         "/www/hosts/${lowercase:%{SERVER_NAME}}/docs/$1"

In the end, all your users do is update a CNAME record, and update the config on your site.  Once set up on your end, this is easy to maintain.

  [1]: https://httpd.apache.org/docs/trunk/rewrite/vhosts.html

answers.body_markdown:
The error indicates that the directory is not accessible on the server. If `/Users/yan/...` is a directory on your laptop, it will not be accessible on the server, so first use a directory on the server as output for `mysqldump`, and than copy the resulting file to your laptop e.g. using [scp](https://linux.die.net/man/1/scp).

As an example, on the server (using a temporary folder):

    mysqldump ... > /tmp/mydb_db.sql

On the laptop:

    scp root@xxx.xx.xxx.xx:/tmp/mydb_db.sql /Users/yan/projects/loc/myweb/db/mydb_db.sql

Note that you should use a directory on the server where only you has access permissions.

answers.title: converting diagonal style row to single row

answers.body_markdown:
Break your table up into separate views by column, then join the views back together by ROWNUM:

    WITH cteA AS (SELECT ROWNUM AS RN, A FROM DATA_TABLE WHERE A IS NOT NULL),
         cteB AS (SELECT ROWNUM AS RN, B FROM DATA_TABLE WHERE B IS NOT NULL),
         cteC AS (SELECT ROWNUM AS RN, C FROM DATA_TABLE WHERE C IS NOT NULL)
    SELECT A, B, C
      FROM cteA
      INNER JOIN cteB USING (RN)
      INNER JOIN cteC USING (RN)

If you happen to have a database which doesn't support `WITH` you can do the same thing with sub-selects:

    SELECT A, B, C
      FROM (SELECT ROWNUM AS RN, A FROM DATA_TABLE WHERE A IS NOT NULL)
      INNER JOIN (SELECT ROWNUM AS RN, B FROM DATA_TABLE WHERE B IS NOT NULL)
        USING (RN)
      INNER JOIN (SELECT ROWNUM AS RN, C FROM DATA_TABLE WHERE C IS NOT NULL)
        USING (RN)

answers.body_markdown:
You can use a `LEAD` analytical function with `ROWNUM` (if you have `ID` in your table which contains values for ordering the records then you can use that `ID` column instead of `ROWNUM`) as follows:

    SELECT * FROM 
    (SELECT A, 
    LEAD(B,ROWNUM) IGNORE NULLS OVER (ORDER BY ROWNUM) AS B,
    LEAD(C,ROWNUM) IGNORE NULLS OVER (ORDER BY ROWNUM) AS C
    FROM YOUR_TABLE)
    WHERE A IS NOT NULL;

[db<>fiddle demo][1]

Cheers!!


  [1]: https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=oracle_11.2&fiddle=6d16db3049e06da4810c3db1c0854d5b

Finally, I got my answer, after scratching my head for sometime.
We can automate the process also.

You can manually backup your (postgres) data using following commands-

 1. Open the running database container using `exec -it` command.

        docker container exec -it  <container-name> bash -l

 2. Create a `/backup` directory, then run following command.

        pg_dump -h localhost -U postgres  yavdhesh -Fc > /backup/db.dump 

    Or you can run the following command also.

        pg_dumpall -l "yavdhesh" -U "yavdhesh" -W  > db.dump

 3. To backup your data. 

        psql -d yavdhesh -U yavdhesh -f db.dump 

    Or you can run following command :

        pg_restore -d db_name /backup/dump_name.tar -c -U "yavdhesh"

These commands are specifically for postgres, but you can take these as reference to create your own commands.
Hope it helps.

answers.body_markdown:
I'm just assuming your input data as parquet format:

1. Create InputRDD from your input location  
2. Transform InputRDD into dataframe using "toDf" function  
3. Create Two schema structures for both **Key** column and **Value** columns  
4. Transform to new dataframe by adding new columns by sending your jsontype columns as input argument to **from_json** function along with schema structure

    

example:    

    val Sampledata_df = spark.read.parquet("path/to/input.parquet")  
    

    val key_Json_Schema = StructType(Seq( 
                                       StructField("foo", StringType, true)
                                    ))
    val value_Json_Schema = StructType(Seq(
                                      StructField("baz", StringType, true) 
                                    ))   

   
    val Parsed_df = Sampledata_df
                   .withColumn("parsed_key", from_json(col("key"), key_Json_Schema))
                   .withColumn("pased_value", from_json(col("value"), value_Json_Schema))


    val Output_df = Parsed_df
                    .withColumn("output_key", $"parsed_key.foo")
                    .withColumn("output_value", $"pased_value.baz")
                    .select($"output_key",$"output_value")

answers.body_markdown:
You are decoding the whole image for each crop position. Try changing your loop to be:

    def split_images(name, labels):
        imsource = Image.open('train_images/{}.jpg'.format(name))
        boundingboxes = np.array(labels.split(' ')).reshape(-1, 5)
    
        for (unicode, x, y, w, h) in boundingboxes:
            try:
                # Create target Directory
                os.mkdir('unicodes/{}'.format(str(unicode)))
            except FileExistsError:
                None
    
            (x, y, w, h) = (int(x), int(y), int(w), int(h))
            cropped_image = imsource.crop((x, y, x + w, y + h))
            cropped_image.save('unicodes/{}/{}.jpg'.format(unicode, name))

You have the `mkdir` inside the loop too, it might help a bit to move that out, if you can. Maybe make one pass over `labels` first to get an array of unique directory names that need creating.

You could try in other image processing libraries, but crop and save is extremely simple, so I doubt if it would make much difference.

I guess this is training a network, is that right? You can get a very big speedup by sending the cropped patches directly to pytorch or whatever you are using rather than going via JPG files. You could consider generating the set of rotates and flips at the same time.

answers.body_markdown: The script is trying to run `/home/diamonddoesnt/Library/Android/sdk/platform-tools/adb`, fully qualified. Your adb is in your PATH, but it's not there. When you try to run a program with a fully qualified path, it doesn't bother checking your PATH if it doesn't find it there. When you just run it as `adb`, it does check your PATH, explaining the difference. To fix it, do `which adb` to figure out where the binary really is, and reconfigure the script to use that one.

answers.body_markdown:
# Terminology

First of all let's figure out what is a labeled and unlabeled tree and how they could be represented as data structures.

> If I have an unlabeled tree with integer leafs. 

There is no such thing as an unlabeled tree with integer leaves. A [tree][1] could be either labeled, i.e., when nodes are assigned labels or, unlabeled,  i.e., when nodes are not assigned any labels. 

Usually, when we speak of trees in the context of computer science we think about labeled trees. And when we speak of labeled trees, we usually are thinking about trees where every node has a label. 

Storing data only on leaf nodes is usually inefficient since we have to use a tree with more layers to store the same set of elements since each layer of a k-ary tree can store up to k^(h-1) elements, where `h` is the depth of the layer. And if we will not use inner nodes for storing data, we will end up throwing away k^(h-2) nodes. Despite this, such trees still exist in production and find their uses in some specialized applications, such as [B+ trees][2] or [Huffman][3] trees.

Now, let's look into the [unlabeled trees][4]. Despite the fact that they are the essence of trees, they are not used very often in the context of computer science and pose of a mathematical interest rather than practical. An unlabeled tree encodes only the structure and nothing more since there is nothing associated with nodes. Unlabeled trees are studied in [combinatorics][5], could be used to represent molecular structures, and in general to represent different kinds of automata and study isomorphism between structures. 

# Tree data structures

## Inductive Definition

There are two approaches to encoding a tree. The canonical way is to use inductive data types, e.g., in OCaml, an unlabeled binary tree is encoded as,

    type tree = Empty | Tree of tree * tree

On the first glance it, again, looks quite useless and bogus. But we can draw an analogy with another simple inductive definition,

    type nat = Zero | Succ of nat 


which is the well-known [Peano][5] encoding of natural numbers. We can easily see, that an unlabeled tree is an extension of Peano numbers (e.g., instead of a unary `Succ` constructor we have binary `Tree` constructor). At the same time we can find out that Peano encoding is nothing more than an unlabeled list, e.g., consider the definition of the list data structure:

    type 'a list = Empty | List of 'a * 'a list

Therefore an unlabeled list, i.e., a list that can't carry anything is still finding its uses, despite the fact, that the only notion that it can encode is its length - which is the essence of the natural numbers - the idea of counting. 

The same is true with unlabeled trees, as they denote the simple idea of decision making and each unlabeled tree encodes a distinct element in a space of decisions. 

While storing numbers as lists and decisions as trees might look like a waste of space, they still have their uses in the face of [Curry-Howard Isomorphism][7], where each constructible data structure acts as a proof term. And therefore such structures become objects of study in the whole field of automatic theorem proving. 

## Representing trees as graphs

It is also [well-known][8] that a tree is a special kind of graph, therefore another natural representation of a tree would be a graph, e.g., using an [adjacency list][9] to represent a graph, we can have the following definition of a tree.

    type tree = (node * node) list

This definition poses a question, what is the `node` type? Indeed, we now need a separate type to bear our graph. In general, we just need to be able to distinguish between two nodes, thus any data type that has an equality operation defined on it will suffice. We can use `int` or `string` for example. Therefore a simple tree with three nodes will be represented as a set of two branches `[1,2; 1,3]` where each branch is an ordered tuple of two nodes. 

The main problem with such representation is that it is not tight enough, as it is possible to construct trees that are not trees, e.g., `[1,2; 2,1]` is a well-formed value of our `tree` type, but it is not a tree, since it has a loop. Therefore, in order to preserve the tree structure of our graph we should always check on each insertion whether a loop is created or any other invariant of a tree is broken (e.g., a cross-edge is inserted). Another issue, is that one has to provide a source of distinct integers for each fresh node. 

Therefore, the inductive definition of a tree bears a nice property - it is always correct. Every instance of an inductive tree is a tree which is proved by construction. Moreover, in the inductive definition, every new node is actually a fresh new object created in the heap, so they are automatically distinct. Basically, it is the language runtime which is responsible for creating new nodes for us. 

However, what is good in the graph representation, and why I'm showing it here, is that it blends the difference between the node and the node label, so it is now very easy to confuse it. Indeed, if we already need to provide some data type to bear nodes (only to make one node distinct from another), then why not to use the same data type to store some labels, i.e., we can use labels themselves as the bearing set, e.g., `["Bil", "Adam"; "Bil", "Eve"]`. And this is indeed a representation that is used quite often in computing. The inductive definition doesn't really provide such freedom. 

     

# Problems with your code

First of all, your data definitions are inconsistent, e.g., the expression

     Node( Node(1,2) , Node(2,3) )

is not well-defined because you're passing to the `Node` constructor both ints, e.g., `1` or `2`, and values that are constructed by the `Node` constructor, e.g., `Node (1,2)`. Therefore it is not well-typed code, since `Node(1,2)` is having the same type as `1`, which is obviously incorrect.

A tree is a recursive data type, so its constructors should accept values of the same type as the tree itself. Of course, in order to construct a recursive data type, you should have a non-recursive constructor, so that you can enter the recursion, e.g., here is an example of an unlabeled tree

    type tree = Empty | Node of tree * tree

As you can see, there is no place for `int` or any other payload in this definition. This is how an _unlabeled_ tree will look like. Contrary to your example, where nodes are parametrized with some integer values. 

Now, we are ready to define a labeled tree. It is obviously a different type, therefore it should have different data constructors, e.g.<sup>1</sup>,

    type ltree = LEmpty | LNode of ltree * int * ltree


Now, let's look into an example of an unlabeled and labeled tree, e.g., the example that is closest to your attempt would be

    let unlabeled = Node (Node (Empty,Empty), Node (Empty, Empty))


Now, let's imagine the corresponding labeled tree, where each node is parametrized by the sum of depths of both subtrees, e.g.,

    let labeled = LNode (LNode (LEmpty, 2, LEmpty), LNode (LEmpty, 2, LEmpty))


If I would be writing a function that will translate from the former representation to the latter, then I will start with the `height` function, that will take an unlabeled tree and compute its depth. And then I will write the `translate` function that will recursively map each unlabeled node to a labeled one. Both are trivial, therefore I'm leaving it to you as an exercise. 

------
<sup>1)</sup> We've prefixed both our data constructors (starting with the capital letter, e.g., `LEmpty` and `LNode`) and type constructors (starting with a small letter, e.g., `ltree`) with the `L` and `l` letter to distinguish it from the unlabeled tree. It is better to use modules for proper namespacing your constuctors, but this is a completely different story. 




[1]: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/enumeration-of-binary-trees/
[2]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B+_tree
[3]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huffman_coding
[4]: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Tree.html
[5]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(graph_theory)#Unlabeled_trees
[6]: https://wiki.haskell.org/Peano_numbers#targetText=Peano%20numbers%20are%20a%20simple,arithmetic%20due%20to%20their%20simplicity.
[7]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curry%E2%80%93Howard_correspondence
[8]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(graph_theory)
[9]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adjacency_list

answers.body_markdown:
Whether the tree is balanced or not has no impact on annotating the tree.

As @ivg points out, your example code, `Node( Node(1,2) , Node(2,3) )`, doesn't make sense because the nodes are storing both child nodes and numbers, which have different types. The correct way to do this is:

```
type tree =
  | Leaf of int (* Leaves store numbers *)
  | Node of tree * tree

let tree = Node(Node(Leaf 1, Leaf 2), Node(Leaf 2, Leaf 3))
```

A tree where each node can have a label, including the inner nodes, could be encoded as 

```
type tree' =
  | Leaf' of int
  | Node' of tree' * int * tree'

let tree' = Node'(Node'(Leaf' 1, 3, Leaf' 2), 8, Node'(Leaf' 2, 5, Leaf' 3))
```

To annotate a tree:

```
let weight : tree' -> int = function
  | Leaf' n -> n (* The weight of a leaf is its data *)
  | Node'(_, n, _) -> n (* The weight of a node is its middle value *)

let rec annot_tree : tree -> tree' = function
  | Leaf n -> Leaf' n (* Base case *)
  | Node(l, r) ->
      let labeled_l = annot_tree l in (* Annotate left child *)
      let labeled_r = annot_tree r in (* Annotate right child *)
      Node'(labeled_l, weight labeled_l + weight labeled_r, labeled_r)
```

answers.body_markdown:
Two things straight up:

1. Run `npm init -y` to initialise a `package.json` file to track your dependencies. Then when you run `npm i ${package}` the package you install will be added to your package.json. This allows you (and others) to install all dependencies with `npm i`.

2. Put your `require` statements at the top of the file, and assign them to constants, rather than requiring in-line. This makes your dependencies easier to read and reason about, and means that your program will fail fast if a dependency is missing, rather than when a statement is evaluated at run-time.

answers.body_markdown:
The [`Unique`][1] constraint is meant for collections (meaning: a field, that holds a collection), and determines, if all entries are unique.

What you probably want:

The [`UniqueEntity`][2] constraint - it must be set on the entity, not the fields, but you can set it twice and once for each field, and set its `fields` property to the appropriate field respectively.


  [1]: https://symfony.com/doc/current/reference/constraints/Unique.html
  [2]: https://symfony.com/doc/current/reference/constraints/UniqueEntity.html

answers.body_markdown:
Try a union query:

    SELECT PLAYER, AVG(hit) AS avg_hits
    FROM
    (
        SELECT PLAYER, hit
        FROM mlb_2017
        UNION ALL
        SELECT PLAYER, hit
        FROM mlb_2018
    ) t
    GROUP BY PLAYER;

The idea behind the union query is that it brings the hit data for each player, for both 2017 and 2018, into a single intermediate table, which we can then aggregate to find the averages.

I would defenitely opt for the 1.) 

Option 2.) has in my opinion the disadvanteges, that it 

 1. takes more CPU (you repeatedly do stuff), more Time, more Bandwith, 
 2. is more error prone/unreliable (every little network outage of the distributions package repo  would lead to a broken build, or every other problem on this level. And you want to keep your CI/CD piplinne es focused as possible to the build of the software itself. Maybe thats the most important part. If a build fails a big red light should go up in your office. If you do professional software dev, as you do, you require a Docker/Container Repository anyway to upload your build artifacts, normally packaged as a container. I have just started experimenting with CI/CD. I want to create a CI/CD pipeline for my project which builds/tests my application on Linux, MacOS, and Windows. For the Linux part, I need to use a specific Docker container (`quay.io/pypa/manylinux2010_x86_64:latest`). Before starting the build in the container I do the usual setup (e.g., `yum -y upgrade`, install `CMake`, etc). And this is where I am starting to get confused. To my understanding, and after spending sometime Googling, the two most common ways to do that are the following:

1) Build a new Docker container which is based on `quay.io/pypa/manylinux2010_x86_64:latest` but also comes with other dependencies installed. An example `Dockerfile` would be the following:

    FROM quay.io/pypa/manylinux2010_x86_64:latest

    RUN yum -y upgrade \
        yum clean all \
        rm -rf /var/cache/yum \
        git clone https://github.com/Kitware/CMake.git \
        cd CMake \
        git checkout -b build v3.15.3 \
        ./configure \
        make \
        make install \
        cd .. \
        rm -r CMake

This container is built once and stored in a repository. Then, every time the CI/CD pipeline runs, it fetches and uses this container.

2) Use the `quay.io/pypa/manylinux2010_x86_64:latest` image in the CI/CD pipeline directly and make the `yum -y upgrade` and `CMake` installation commands part of the CI/CD pipeline scripts. This means that every time the CI/CD pipeline runs, it: (a) fetches the docker image, (b) starts the container, (c) runs `yum` and installs the dependencies.

- Given my use-case, could you please help me choose which approach is the right one for me?

answers.body_markdown:
The easiest way to manipulate a URL is to first get it into its parsed form.  Use `URL` for this:

    const url = new URL(location.href);

On that URL object are two properties you're interested in.  The first is `host`, which specifies the hostname and port number.  In your example, your first URL would have the `host` set to `123.123.123.123:8080`.  You could change this to `123.123.123.123:8082` like so:

    url.host = '123.123.123.123:8082';

Then to get the string form of the URL:

    url.toString(); // http://123.123.123.123:8082/home

The next property you want to manipulate is `pathname`, and it works the same way.  Just modify that to change the path, and use the `url` as a string to get the string version.

Also, unrelated to your question, but please consider using the designated documentation IP addresses in your questions in the future.  https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5737  You never know when you might use an example address that might actually be in use by someone.

items.body_markdown:
I am trying to speed up the Rolling Root Mean Square Deviation Calculation and am stuck with a semi-optimized code. This is my code:

---
Original Root Mean Square Deviation(this function runs fast when n is small, but greatly suffers from large `n` values)

    import numpy as np
    from numba import njit, prange

    @njit(parallel=True)
    def rt_mean_sq_dev(array1, array2, n):
        result = np.empty(array1.shape[0])
        result[:n-1] = np.nan
        
        for i in prange(n-1,array1.shape[0]):
            result[i] = np.sqrt(np.sum(np.square(array1[i+1-n:i+1] - array2[i]))/n)
        return result


---
Semi-optimized Root Mean Square Deviation(constant run-time regardless of the size of `n`

    @njit  
    def rt_mean_sq_dev4(array1, array2, n):
        msd_temp = np.empty(array1.shape[0])
        
        K = array2[n-1]
        
        rs_x= array1[0] - K
        rs_xsq = rs_x *rs_x
        
        msd_temp[0] = np.nan
        
        for i in range(1,n):#first part of the cumsum for x adn xsq
            rs_x += array1[i] - K
            rs_xsq += np.square(array1[i] - K)
            msd_temp[i] = np.nan
           
        y_i = array2[n-1] - K
        msd_temp[n-1] = np.sqrt(max(y_i*y_i + (rs_xsq - 2*y_i*rs_x)/n, 0))
        
        for i in range(n, array1.shape[0]):
            rs_x = array1[i] - array1[i-n]+ rs_x
            rs_xsq = np.square(array1[i] - K) - np.square(array1[i-n] - K) + rs_xsq
            y_i = array2[i] - K
            
            msd_temp[i] = np.sqrt(max(y_i*y_i + (rs_xsq - 2*y_i*rs_x)/n, 0))
            
        return msd_temp 

    if __name__ == '__main__':
        
        np.random.seed(0)
        data_size = 200000
        
        data_c = np.random.uniform(0,1000, size = data_size)+29000
        data_d = data_c  + np.random.uniform(0,1, size = data_size)
        
        
        tail = np.tile(30000,200)
        data_c = np.hstack((data_c, tail))
        data_d = np.hstack((data_d, tail))
        
        N = 3
        test4 = rt_mean_sq_dev4(data_c, data_d,  N )

When `n = 7000`, the original function takes about `320ms` per loop while `rt_mean_sq_dev4` merely takes `2.6ms`; when `n = 3` however, the original function takes `1.3ms` and this function stays the same, about `2.5ms`. So overall `rt_mean_sq_dev4` is faster and is preferred.

`rt_mean_sq_dev4` is so far my best attempt at the problem, using some sort of rolling cumsum structures in the for-loop. I have tried creating `numpy` arrays to "store" some previous calculated squared values inside the second loop in order to save some calculation time before, but to my surprise the change actually makes the function runs slower. 

I can't help but feel that there's got to be some much better ways to implement the calculations that I am just not aware of it yet; or there could be small but important techniques to further speed up my code that I just don't know yet; or there are some `scipy` functions that do exactly what I am attempting to do but faster that I just don't know yet, which is why I am asking for help here. 

---

Side Notes:

1) The `K` in `rt_mean_sq_dev4` is a correction term to improve the accuracy of the function by reducing the effect of catastrophic cancellation; this idea is inspired from [here][1]

---
EDIT1: forgot to type `np.sum()` in my original function `rt_mean_sq_dev`. That may have caused confusions to any readers to this question. My apologies

  [1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithms_for_calculating_variance

answers.body_markdown:
Unfortunately, **as of PowerShell Core 7.0.0-preview.3, PowerShell offers _no_ way to automatically exit a script when an _external program_ reports a nonzero exit code.**

  * **Adding support is being discussed** in [this RFC proposal](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-RFC/pull/88).

  * For *PowerShell-native* commands *only* (cmdlets, scripts, functions), `$ErrorActionPreference = 'Stop'` can be used, which results in exit code `1`.
    * If you need more control over what exit code is reported, see [this answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/53248925/45375).
    * For an overview of how PowerShell reports exit codes to the outside world, see [this answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/57468523/45375).

  * For now, you must **test for `$LASTEXITCODE -eq 0` _explicitly_** and take action based on that, but as a **workaround** you can **use a *helper function*** for all external-program invocations, as shown in [this answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/48877892/45375).

Text widget indexes aren't floating point numbers. They are strings of the form _line_._character_, which is why converting them to floating point numbers and attempting to do math won't work.

Text widget identifiers accept modifiers. In your case you want `-2chars` (or `-2c`) added to your index to subtract two character positions from the base index. You can use the `index` method to convert an index with modifiers into just an index if you want to see the end result of the modifications.

    end_itlc = self.editor.index("{}-2chars".format(end_itlc))

answers.body_markdown:
Notice that in your code, the if and elif statements are labelled as 
```longest_seq[i] == "-" or "?"```. What you need to do is evaluate each statement individually, like the below code.

```
    if (longest_seq[i] == "-") or (longest_seq[i] == "?"):
        print ((i+1), longest_seq[i], shortest_seq[i])
    elif (longest_seq[i] == "-") or (longest_seq[i] == "?"):
        print ((i+1), longest_seq[i], shortest_seq[i])
```

As to why this happens, take a look at this fun illustration below:
[![enter image description here][1]][1]

The 3 == '-' is evaluated first, to FALSE, but when combined with the or '?' evaluates to '?'. The '?' value is not 'false' so the if statement goes **YOLO** and decides to proceed anyway. 


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/gTGYL.png

In project settings, under the build phases tab, create a new "Copy Bundle Resources" build phase (if there isn't one already). Build phases are things that happen while the bundle is being built. "Copy Bundle Resources" copies files into the `Resources` folder of the bundle.

[![screenshot][1]][1]

Copy [ResourcePath.hpp](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SFML/SFML/489482a630c5286e488ffc270c10562809056d8e/tools/xcode/templates/SFML/SFML%20App.xctemplate/ResourcePath.hpp) and [ResourcePath.mm](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/SFML/SFML/489482a630c5286e488ffc270c10562809056d8e/tools/xcode/templates/SFML/SFML%20App.xctemplate/ResourcePath.mm) into your project. The `resourcePath()` function returns the path to the resources folder in the bundle.

```C++
sf::Texture texture;
texture.loadFromFile(resourcePath() + "mario.png");
```

To verify that the file is in the bundle, find the bundle...

[![screenshot][2]][2]

then open the bundle...

For more information, see [the tutorial](https://www.sfml-dev.org/tutorials/2.5/start-osx.php).

answers.body_markdown:
As per [XPath Syntax article][1]

> `.` - Selects the current node

So you should be able to search the next element relative to the previous element, something like:

    WebElement element1 = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//*[@id='validation-item-0']/div[3]/div/div[2]/ul/li[16]"));
    WebElement element2 = element1.findElement(By.xpath("./ul[1]/li/ul/li[4]"));

    

I would recommend getting rid of this `div[3]`, `li[16]`, etc. as even slight [markup][2] change will ruin your expression and test. Be aware that you can use [XPath Axes][3]  like [descendant][4] so your expression would be more robust and reliable

Also this `ul[16]` doesn't look good, `<ul>` tag stands for the [Unordered List][5] so you my expectation is that you should not be using index, but rather stick to the element text, something like:

    WebElement myElement = driver.findElement(By.xpath("//ul[contains(text(),'element text here')]"));

where [`contains()`][6] is the [XPath Function][7] which could be used for partial match on the text 

     


  [1]: https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xpath_syntax.asp
  [2]: https://www.quora.com/What-is-markup-in-HTML
  [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/XPath/Axes
  [4]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/XPath/Axes/descendant
  [5]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/ul
  [6]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/XPath/Functions/contains
  [7]: https://docs.experitest.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=40044727

answers.body_markdown:
The ambiguity in your query comes from `SELECT supplier_id`

You can see in your join statement, you are joining two tables that share the ***exact same column name***. Since you have joined them, you now have access to select ANY column from either of those two tables.

When you simply write `SELECT supplier_id`, the database doesn't know if you want the `supplier_id` column from `suppliers`, or from `product`, so it is giving you this error. You need to change your code to:

    SELECT supplier.supplier_id, name, count(*) 
    from supplier 
      join product on supplier.supplier_id = product.supplier_id
    group by name  HAVING COUNT(*) > 2

OR

    SELECT product.supplier_id, name, count(*) 
    from supplier 
      join product on supplier.supplier_id = product.supplier_id
    group by name  HAVING COUNT(*) > 2

So that way, you specify the table which `supplier_id` comes from (you'll have to do the same for name if that is the case, but you didn't provide exampled data or an ER diagram, so we can't tell for sure)

answers.body_markdown:
Taken at face value, the problems include:

**Q1** `struct abc *ptr; printf("%d\n", ptr->field);`

1. The structure type is not complete so we have no way of knowing whether the structure has a member `field`.
2. The variable `ptr` is not initialized, so it cannot safely be dereferenced even if the type is known.
3. Because we don't know the type of `field`, we can't say whether the `printf()` format is OK or not.

**Q2** `char *ptr = malloc(sizeof(ptr));`

1. The space allocated for the 'string' is the size of a pointer, which is probably not the wanted size.
2. One common idiom is `SomeType *ptr = malloc(sizeof(*ptr));` to allocate enough space for a single object of type `SomeType`.  This is close but not quite there.
3. Adapting the idiom for an array of `N` objects (where `N` is a suitable integer value), you'd use `SomeType *ptr = malloc(N * sizeof(*ptr));` instead.

**Q3** `char *ptr = malloc(1000); memset(&ptr, 0, 1000);`

1. The allocation isn't checked.
2. The `memset()` should be passed the pointer value, not the address of the pointer:

  `memset(ptr, '\0', 1000);`

  but why not have the data zeroed by the memory allocation code using:

  `char *ptr = calloc(1000, sizeof(*ptr));`

answers.body_markdown:
Cross origin resource sharing (cors) is disabled for security reasons, you will need to manually enable it. 
I use a package called **cors** for express based backend. 

 **Step 1**
 ```node
npm install cors
```
 **Step 2**
```node 
const cors = require('cors')
```

**Final step**
```node
app.use(cors())
```


 This will enable [CORS][1] for all routes. You can also enable for individual routes. Check the doc on [github][2]
    


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS
  [2]: https://github.com/expressjs/cors
